awd_titl_txt: Insights into Hawaiian Magma Storage and Melt/Crust Interaction from Geochemical and Petrologic Investigation of Xenoliths from Hualalai and Mauna Kea Volcanoes
awd_abstract_narration:
Compositional variations in lavas erupted from volcanoes such as those that have built the Hawaiian Islands provide insights into the processes that generate magma in Earth's interior. Compositional variations in different portions of Earth's mantle inferred from variations in magma composition also provide insights into how processes such as plate tectonics and mantle convection have shaped the long-term evolution of Earth's interior, which ultimately also influences the evolution of Earth's surface environment and life itself. However, magma storage, mixing, and interaction with crustal rocks can affect the compositions of magmas before they erupt at the surface. These processes can also influence whether volcanic eruptions are explosive or not, and thus influence volcanic hazards. This project will study the compositions of crystalline aggregates (or cumulates) brought to the surface by erupting lava flows in Hawaii. These cumulates are probably formed at depth within Hawaiian magma is stored temporarily and are later were carried to the surface by Hawaiian magmas. The compositions of these crystalline cumulates provide a record of the depths of magma storage and processes such as magma cooling and crystallization, mixing of discrete magma batches, and assimilation of the surrounding rock during magma ascent. The results of this study will provide a better understanding of the so-called "plumbing system" of Hawaiian volcanoes, allow us to better interpret the compositional observed in erupted lavas, and may help us explain why many Hawaiian volcanoes appear to alternate between periods of non-explosive eruptions (low volcanic hazard) and explosive eruptions (much higher volcanic hazard). Results of this research will be incorporated into outreach lectures and exhibits, specifically the "Hot Science Cool Talks" program and the annual "Explore University of Texas" open house, both of which draw a large number of local elementary-, middle- and high-school-age children to the institution. This project will also support the training and development of both graduate and undergraduate students, preparing them for careers in the Geologic Sciences.

This project will examine geochemical variations in xenoliths hosted in recent post-shield-stage lavas from Hualalai and Mauna Kea volcanoes. These plutonic samples, which include rare fragments of Pacific oceanic crust as well as cumulates of Hawaiian shield- and post-shield magmas, provide powerful constraints on the temporal evolution and spatial variation of Hawaiian magma storage and transport systems, and will allow us to evaluate the potential roles of melt/lithosphere, melt/crust, and melt/edifice interaction in generating chemical and isotopic signatures (or scatter) in Hawaiian lavas. Mineral major element compositions and petrologic modeling will be combined with supporting trace element, radiogenic (Sr-Nd-Pb-Hf-Os) and stable O isotope data to constrain the nature of parental magmas (shield tholeiities or post-shield alkali basalts) that produced different xenolith populations, and the depths at which these magmas ponded and fractionated. This will provide a 4-D picture of how Hawaiian magmatic plumbing evolves over time, and whether it varies between Kea- and Loa-trend volcanoes. Integration of isotopic and trace element data with mineral major element data will allow us to examine how both the overall isotopic compositions and isotopic variability in Hawaiian xenoliths varies as a function of formation depth, degree of melt fractionation, or volcanic stage. Specific questions to be addressed including 1) Over what range of depths do Hawaiian magmas pond and fractionate? Does magma storage depth vary significantly from volcano to volcano (e.g., between Kea-trend and Loa-trend volcanoes) or within individual volcanoes during different stages of volcanism (e.g., shield and post-shield volcanism)? 2) To what extent does crustal assimilation, melt/lithosphere interaction, or "self assimilation" within the volcanic edifice affect the final compositions of Hawaiian lavas, and how does this vary between Hawaiian shield-stage, post-shield-stage, and rejuvenation-stage lavas? 3) What role does magma mixing and homogenization play in damping small-scale heterogeneities from discrete melt batches? Can plutonic xenoliths provide additional insight into the nature and length-scales of Hawaiian plume heterogeneities This research is expected to contribute significantly to our understanding of Hawaiian magma storage, mixing, and assimilation processes.

por.por_cntn:
Hawaiian volcanoes have a complex magma plumbing system. Melts generated from the Hawaiian plume are stored at various depths before erupting at the surface. During storage, interaction with surrounding wallrocks from the Pacific crust or mantle or previously erupted Hawaiian lavas can change the compositions of Hawaiian melts. Understanding the processes that affect melts as they ascend is important for understanding how the compositions of erupted lavas can be used to interpret mantle structure and processes. This project examined the chemical and isotopic composition of xenoliths erupted at two Hawaiian volcanoes, Mauna Kea and Hualalai, to constrain the depths at which Hawaiian magmas pond and undergo modification, and the chemical and isotopic signatures that result from melt/wallrock interaction. Many xenoliths contained in Hawaiian basalt represent crystal cumulates that form when Hawaiian magmas pond, cool, and undergo partial crystallization at depth. The chemical compositions of these xenoliths therefore provide a window into the compositions of Hawaiian magmas at depth. In addition, rare xenoliths from Hualalai volcano have chemical and isotopic signatures that indicate they derive from the pre-existing Pacific oceanic crust through which Hawaiian magmas must pass to reach the surface.

The major element compositions of minerals is affected by the pressure and temperature of formation. We used the mineral compositions to calculate the pressures and temperatures at which these xenoliths derived. This allowed us to determine xenolith depths of origins. Many Hualalai xenoliths derive from near the base of the Pacific crust. Magmas tend to pond at this depth because of the density contrast between the crust and mantle. However, some xenoliths also formed at shallower depths, within the Hawaiian volcanic edifices constructed on top of the Pacific crust. In contrast, most xenoliths from Mauna Kea formed at shallow depths, during magma ponding within the volcano itself.

When magmas pond, they transfer heat to the surrounding wallrock. Cooling of the magma results in partial crystallization, and settling of these crystals changes the composition of the magma. For example, the iron to magnesium ratio of magmas tends to increase during cooling, so we used this ratio to determine the degree of cooling that the magma source of each xenolith had undergone. Furthermore, heat transferred to the surrounding wallrock causes this material to partially melt, and these melts can become mixed into the magma, changing its composition. For Mauna Kea xenoliths, there is a strong correlation between the degree of magma fractionation and the oxygen isotope composition of the xenoliths. This correlation is explained by an ?assimilation/fractional crystallization? process, whereby cooling magma melts and then assimilates wallrock material that has a distinct isotope composition. Large variations in oxygen isotopes are mainly found in rocks that have interacted with circulating hydrothermal fluids. We determined that Manua Kea magmas assimilated previously-erupted lavas that had undergone hydrothermal alteration. This is an important result, because some previous studies had interpreted oxygen isotope variations in Mauna Kea lavas as reflecting variations in the composition of the Hawaiian plume. We showed that this interpretation is incorrect.

At Hualalai, there are also variations in xenolith composition that relate to the degree of parent magma cooling and the depth of formation. Some xenoliths that formed at shallow depths show similar oxygen isotope signatures of edifice assimilation as observed at Mauna Kea. However, other xenoliths show evidence for assimilation of pre-existing Pacific oceanic crust. This result is significant, because many studies have used the isotopic signatures of Hawaiian lavas to constrain the structure and composition of the Hawaiian plume. Our results show that not all isotopic variations derive from the plume itself ? the chemical evolution of magmas as they ascend to the surface has to be constrained to derive a clear picture of plume composition.

Finally, we found that the Pacific crust showed evidence for having been affected by interaction with Hawaiian melts. This interaction changed the original composition to produce a ?hybrid? component that is isotopically similar to lavas erupted at Hawaiian volcanoes during the waning stages of their activity. Again, previous studies had suggested that this unique signature reflected a specific component in the Hawaiian plume. Our results suggest that melting of the Pacific mantle or crust following interaction with earlier Hawaiian melts might explain this signature.

This project also supported training of two graduate students and one undergraduate student, helped support laboratory facilities that are widely used by many faculty and students for a range of projects, and our findings are being incorporated into both classroom material and for outreach to the general public.

In summary, this project increased our understanding of how Hawaiian magmas pond and evolve as they ascend to the surface, how this influences their composition, and how this impacts our ability to use basalt compositions to interpret the nature of the Hawaiian plume that is ultimately responsible for Hawaiian volcanism.

 


Last Modified: 07/07/2022
Modified by: John C Lassiter

Image

    John Lassiter

    Oxygen isotope variation in Hawaiian xenoliths
